content.title: Hispter mood at Mama Shelter

introduction.small: Near the Strovmoka Park, Prague's green lung, Mama Shelter is the promise of a trendy stay, from which it is easy to reach all touristic points of interest by foot.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hispter mood at Mama Shelter

paragraphs.text:
For the group's seventh address, Mama Shelter chose to take hold in Prague, about 15 minutes from the Czech capital's historic centre. Neighbours are just as prestigious – the National Gallery, the DOX Contemporary Art Centre, Prague's typical flea market and the Strovmoka Park, which is the biggest in town. Tramways stop at the foot of the hotel and will take you to any district you like.
Mama Shelter's inviting and trendy concept spreads over ten floors and 238 rooms, modern and colourful with graphic and original overtones. Whether at one of the large tables in the vintage restaurant, at the pizzeria or at the bar, you won't have to look far for cocktail, lunch or dinner. For sports enthusiasts, note that the hotel even offers a gym. And when the sun sets in, climb up to the panoramic terrace for a magical 360° view of the “City of the Hundred Spires”.

Mama Shelter
Veletržní 1502/20
170 00 Praha 7

+420 225 117 862

www.mamashelter.com/en/prague

Rooms: from 79 EUR

content.title: At Grils, chicken is king

introduction.small: For the greatest enjoyment of food lovers, Prague's Grils restaurant puts all kinds of poultry in the spotlight.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: At Grils, chicken is king

paragraphs.text:
As the name suggests, everything is based around the grill taking centre stage in the main dining area. At Grils, in Karlin district, poultry is roasted, grilled or flambéed… Launched through crowdfunding, the restaurant is now full all the time. Far from ordinary grill houses that most of the time serve battery chicken, Grils bets on quality: poultry is directly sourced from a small farm near the Czech capital.
In a refined setting – clear wooden furniture and originally shaped chairs – the establishment looking like a bistro from yesteryears mostly welcomes office workers during the week, while families gather for Sunday lunch. Everything goes through the grill, even dessert, for instance using smoked plums. Depending on your hunger level, order a quarter, half or whole chicken, served with seasonal sides, like corn or turnips… grilled obviously!

Grils
U Nádražní lávky 81/2
186 00 Praha 8-Karlín

+420 731 631 835

www.grilskarlin.cz/en/ ﻿

Menu: around 8 EUR

content.title: Creative Pan-Asian flavours at QQ Asian Kitchen

introduction.small: With QQ Asian Kitchen, Prague's Asian gastronomy gets a kick-start with a creative cuisine that showcases various influences.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Creative Pan-Asian flavours at QQ Asian Kitchen

paragraphs.text:
On the banks of the Vltava River, Vietnamese and Chinese communities abound, as locals are fond of their food. Chefs Nyoman Purnata and Lee Chang know a thing or two about this: they are both well-known figures on the Asian food scene in Czech Republic, and have now partnered to start QQ Asian Kitchen, near the Botanical Garden. The interior is sober and inviting, with a wide use of wood and colourful steel chairs.
As the name of the restaurant suggests, the menu – changing every month – presents creative dishes from all over Asia, as a mix of street food and gourmet recipes. For heightened pleasure, the tasting menu will charm adepts and newcomers alike. You may be able to taste the sautéed beef in pepper sauce and snap beans, the pork wok served with bamboo shoots, or the fried salmon teriyaki for instance. Influences may be plural, but the two chefs use local, organic and high-quality ingredients as much as possible. These delicate dishes will leave a lasting impression.

QQ Asian Kitchen
Ladova 2044/3
128 00 Nové Město

+420 223 007 145

www.facebook.com/qqasiankitchen

Menu: around 12.50 EUR

content.title: Immerse yourself in former Czechoslovakia at the Museum of Communism

introduction.small: Since the Velvet Revolution in November 1989, which led to the political independence of Czechoslovakia, the country's history is not to be forgotten… An authentic return to a difficult period.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Immerse yourself in former Czechoslovakia at the Museum of Communism

paragraphs.text:
A stone's throw from Wenceslas Square, the Museum of Communism provides a fascinating glimpse into the eponymous era in Czechoslovakia, from 1921 to 1989. Founded in 2001, it opposes the idealized view of Communism, as it was presented at the time, to the reality experienced by the people. Its story focuses on everyday life, political and economic issues, education, the military and the arts.
Stone-faced Lenin welcomes you at the entrance of the museum. Without omission or taboo, the exhibition space invites you to immerse yourself in Communist Prague and its authentic history… Reproductions and projections are packed with information for the new generation, who is becoming aware of the country's upsetting history.

Museum of Communism
Na Příkope 10
110 00 Praha 1
+420 224 212 966
muzeumkomunismu.cz

content.title: The Dancing House enchants Prague

introduction.small: If you have never seen a building dance, you have to go to Prague. On the banks of the Vltava, this house appears to twist and turn before your eyes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Dancing House enchants Prague

paragraphs.text:
As you walk along the Rašínovo nábřeží quay, you won't necessarily be surprised by an unusual building: The Dancing House, conceived by Vlado Milunić and Frank Gehry in 1996. This ultramodern building was designed to be static and dynamic, masculine and feminine alike. The two architects were inspired by famous Hollywood musical comedy dancers Fred Astaire, for the stone tower (on the right), and his partner Ginger Rogers, for the glass tower (on the left). While it doesn't really “move”, the house reproduces the shapes of a dancing couple, Fred holding Ginger by the waist, while she softly and gracefully curls up against him.
The office building is also home to a restaurant, Ginger & Fred, as well as a contemporary art gallery aimed at promoting young artists.
On the top floor, the panoramic terrace offers a 360° view of the entire city, where you can admire its other architectural wonders: Prague Castle and St. Vitus Cathedral, Charles Bridge and the Petřín Hill.

La Maison dansante (Tančící dům)
Jiráskovo náměstí 6
Nové Město
120 00 Praha 2
+420 732 675 202
www.galerietancicidum.cz

content.title: The Golden Wheel: low-key cosy

introduction.small: Small, comfortable, romantic, and inexpensive, the Golden Wheel, in the heart of Malá Strana, rests in the shade of Prague Castle.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Golden Wheel: low-key cosy

paragraphs.text:
The Golden Wheel is the antithesis of the posh Augustine Hotel. No streamlined designer furnishings here, just an intimate, romantic ambiance brought on by authentic details: domed or exposed-beam ceilings which sometimes boast Baroque stuccos.

The decor is quirky and widely assorted. The fairly stripped-down rooms are comfortable and contrast nicely with the crowded Art Nouveau reception area, which recalls the obsolete charms of hotels behind the Iron Curtain.

A much-appreciated little hotel which opens onto the cobblestones of the famous Nerudova street near the walls of Prague Castle.

The Golden Wheel
Nerudova 217/28
118 00 Malá Strana

+420 257 535 490

www.thegoldenwheel.com

Rooms: from 97 EUR

content.title: Hotel Yasmin: ultramodern plant walls

introduction.small: The Hotel Yasmin is a lush oasis in the heart of the city. Design and spätzle are served up in Noodles, its popular restaurant.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Yasmin: ultramodern plant walls

paragraphs.text:
The Hotel Yasmin is an oasis of plant design with its greenhouse forest of birches and its clusters of mirror lamps, which give it the feel of a botanical garden.

A bank during the 19th century, the building was transformed in 2006 into an elegant, contemporary, and comfortable hotel. The 197 rooms offer tranquil charm in olive green tones and black-tiled bathrooms. Room prices include a generous buffet for breakfast at Noodles, one of Prague's most frequented restaurants.

In the evening, this ultramodern restaurant serves an international menu based around noodles, pasta, gnocchi, and spätzle. In the summer, sip a cocktail in the garden before exploring some of Prague's best night-time establishments nearby.

Hotel Yasmin
Politických vězňů 913/12
110 00 Nové Město

+420 234 100 100

www.hotel-grandium.cz/en/

Rooms: from 135 EUR

content.title: A thousand years of history at the Prague Castle

introduction.small: Behind its austere facade, Prague Castle encircles a vast collection of churches, palaces, and gardens, which tell the story of Czech political and religious history.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A thousand years of history at the Prague Castle

paragraphs.text:
The Castle is Prague's essential historical monument. By turns a stately, royal, and then imperial residence, today it holds the official residence of the Czech President. Václav Havel had several hares released on the grounds in order ‘to add a little life.'

At the heart of the castle complex is the lavish, Gothic Saint Vitus Cathedral which required five centuries to construct and, as a result, has a Renaissance gallery, a Baroque dome, and sections of stained glass designed by Alphonse Mucha. Prague Castle also boasts Saint George's Basilica which holds some of the most beautiful Roman ruins in the capital.

Sprawling over 70,000 square metres, the castle is listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. A walk in the gardens during the summer is not to be missed, along with a visit to the old royal palace (1502) which blends flamboyant Gothic and early Renaissance elements.

Prague Castle
119 08 Prague 1

+420 224 373 368

www.hrad.cz/en

content.title: The ‘New World Symphony' at the Rudolfinum

introduction.small: The Rudolfinum is where Antonin Dvořák directed the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra's very first concert. Gustav Mahler also premiered his 'Symphony No. 7' here.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The ‘New World Symphony' at the Rudolfinum

paragraphs.text:
Both concert hall and museum, the Rudolfinum, also known as the ‘House of Artists,' hosts both the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra and the Rudolfinum Gallery in a magnificent Neo-Renaissance palace on Jan Palach Square.

The gallery is noted for its temporary exhibits of contemporary artists, while the Dvořák Hall, which has the best acoustics in the city, is one of the oldest and most elegant in Europe.

The Rudolfinum is a feast for both the eyes and ears. The building was designed by Josef Zitek (creator of the National Theatre) and Josef Schulze (designer of the National Museum).

The Rudolfinum
Alšovo nábř. 12
110 00 Praha 1

+420 227 059 227

www.rudolfinum.cz/en

content.title: The atmosphere of the Austro-Hungarian Empire at the Café Louvre

introduction.small: The Café Louvre is the Café Slavia's polar opposite, with its neo-Rococo stuccos. Its comfortable charm goes well with the apple strudel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The atmosphere of the Austro-Hungarian Empire at the Café Louvre

paragraphs.text:
Kafka's closest friend, German writer and journalist Max Brod, wrote: ‘With K. at the Café Louvre, we read Laforgue. Beautiful hours, during which I felt entirely safe.'

At the beginning of the 20th century, the Café Louvre was a meeting place for the ‘Brentanists' intellectual movement from the German University, as well as for members of the Pan-Slavic movement. Cultivated, emancipated women from both camps also held court here. A young Albert Einstein spent time here during his student years. After the Second World War, the Communist regime lowered the curtain on this beautiful establishment.

This Prague institution reopened its doors in 1992, recreating the atmosphere of cafés of the Austro-Hungarian Empire in this spacious, welcoming, and smoker-friendly environment.

Café Louvre
Národní 22
110 00 Nové Město

+420 224 930 949

www.cafelouvre.cz

Menu: from 11 EUR

content.title: Hergetova Cihelna: dinner over the water

introduction.small: Hergetova Cihelna offers quality cuisine in an ideal setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hergetova Cihelna: dinner over the water

paragraphs.text:
Hergetova Cihelna serves traditional Czech, Italian, and fusion cuisine in a decidedly modern setting. Elegant but not overdone, this 18th-century building, which used to be a brick factory, has been transformed into a modern space while maintaining a touch of old-fashioned charm. Pastel yellow walls and stylish lighting meet rustic arches and beams. Reserve in advance for a table on the terrace and enjoy the superb view of the Charles Bridge while savouring a creamy mushroom soup with a poached egg and roasted potatoes, or a royal burger with beef and foie gras, served with homemade fries and caramelised onions. For dessert, go for the chocolate fondant with salted caramel ice cream, a coconut sherbet or a carrot cake with mascarpone.

With its unbeatable location and its relaxed ambience, the Hergetova Cihelna attracts locals as much as tourists.

Hergetova Cihelna
Cihelná 2b
118 00 Malá Strana

+420 296 826 103

www.kampagroup.com

Menu: around 676 CZK

content.title: The Prague Spring at the Municipal House

introduction.small: The versatility of the Municipal House makes it a fitting metaphor for national renewal. The splendour of this monument of Art Nouveau style makes it accessible to all.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Prague Spring at the Municipal House

paragraphs.text:
The Municipal House, constructed to honour the city, carries an allegorical mosaic, the Apotheosis of Prague, on its central gable. Built in 1912 in late Art Nouveau style, it overflows with dazzling ornamental detail.

On the first floor, stateroom upon stateroom lead to the central balcony of the Mayor's Room with a vaulted ceiling decorated by Mucha where Václav Havel announced the return to democracy in 1989. Among the spaces dedicated to culture, the most prestigious is the immense Smetana concert hall, which serves as the venue for the opening of Prague's Spring Festival every year. On the ground floor, the Municipal Café has recovered its former glory.

The French restaurant, with its outsized dining room, recalls the high point of the Belle Époque. An entirely different ambience awaits you in the lower level at Pilsen, a traditional Czech restaurant with long, shared dining tables and an Art Deco style.

Municipal House
Nám. Republiky 5
111 21 Staré Město

+420 222 002 107

www.obecnidum.cz/en

content.title: Beer at Lokál

introduction.small: Lokál is known all over Prague for innovative, relaxed, and affordable food served amidst old-school decor.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Beer at Lokál

paragraphs.text:
Lokál offers a true culinary voyage through the Czech Republic. Its menu is entirely focused on local flavours. The relaxed atmosphere and friendly staff make a winning pair. Servers are happy to translate the day's specials, which run from traditional breaded veal cutlets to creamed beef fillet with a modern twist. Try out the fried cheese with tartare sauce, trout in cumin butter and chocolate-filled coconut meringue for dessert. Local beers flow on tap. Elegant and discreet in white tones and dark wood, the space is very popular. Consider making a booking in spite of the 260 available places.

Lokál
Dlouhá 33
110 00 Staré Město

+420 734 283 874

lokal-dlouha.ambi.cz/en/

Menu: around 541 CZK

content.title: The Old Jewish Cemetery: a stunning necropolis

introduction.small: There have been three dominant cultures in Kafka's city: Czech, German, and Jewish. A visit to the legendary Old Jewish Cemetery is not to be missed.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Old Jewish Cemetery: a stunning necropolis

paragraphs.text:
The Maharal, an abbreviation of Morenou HaRav Loew, (‘Our teacher, Rabbi Loew') is a famous rabbi from 16th-century Prague who died at nearly 100 years old in 1609. His monumental statue can be seen on the facade of Prague's City Hall and, of course, his tomb is in the Old Jewish Cemetery.

An important progressive religious figure, he wrote numerous essays on the ethics and historical philosophy of the Jewish people and was a prominent advocate of the rabbinical allegorical literature, the Midrash. Legend has it that he created the Golem, a monster made of clay, in order to protect the ghetto from persecution.

There are now some 12,000 Gothic, Renaissance, and Baroque tombstones mixed together among the greenery. Burials took place until 1787, when an imperial decree forbade them in the city centre.

Old Jewish Cemetery
Široká
110 00 Staré Město

+420 222 749 211

www.jewishmuseum.cz/pamatky-a-expozice/pamatky/stary-zidovsky-hrbitov/

content.title: The House of the Black Madonna: a work of resistance

introduction.small: Cubism's incursion into Bohemia shook off Prague's dusty image as the provincial capital of the Austro-Hungarian Empire.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The House of the Black Madonna: a work of resistance

paragraphs.text:
Josef Gočár, a member of the famous Mánes circle of artists, designed the House of the Black Madonna as a department store commissioned by the merchant František Josef Herbs.

It emulates French Cubist style (Picasso, Braque) and therefore represented a cultural resistance against the Viennese avant-garde. The building takes its name from the Gothic black virgin perching on one of its parapets. Little by little the building was forgotten until it became a showpiece of avant-garde Czech Cubism as an annex to Prague's National Gallery at the end of 2012.

Today merchants have reclaimed a corner of its history with the opening of a Kubista shop-gallery on the ground floor. On the first floor, the Grand Café Orient has been faithfully restored to its original form after being closed for 80 years.

House of the Black Madonna
Ovocný trh 19
110 00 Staré Město

content.title: Kampa: an island of creativity

introduction.small: The pleasures of artistic life and creation are both to be found in the tiny cobblestoned streets of Kampa Island and in its museum of modern and contemporary Czech art.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kampa: an island of creativity

paragraphs.text:
Descend the Charles Bridge's stairs on the Malá Strana side and discover the magical world of Kampa Island, considered the most beautiful urban island in the world after Paris' Ile Saint-Louis.

Savour the magical charm of a stroll along romantic side streets and the former addresses of numerous Czech artistic personalities. Admire the watermills of houses dating from the 17th and 18th centuries, then head towards the Jan and Meda Mládek Foundation's Kampa Museum for magnificent proof of the intense creative output of Czech and Slovak artists banned under the Communist regime.

There are also works by Cubist precursor Otto Gutfreund and abstractionist pioneer František Kupka.

Kampa Museum – Jan and Meda Mládek Foundation
U Sovových mlýnů 2
118 00 Malá Strana

+420 257 286 147

www.museumkampa.cz

content.title: A romantic stroll on Petřín Hill

introduction.small: Take the funicular up the hill and find the statue of romantic poet Karel Hynek Mácha: steal a kiss in its shade or consider ‘the sweetness of a secret pain'…

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A romantic stroll on Petřín Hill

paragraphs.text:
If you are looking for peace, the very pretty park on Petřín Hill offers a romantic afternoon. Climb aboard the charming Victorian funicular railway, which hoists you to a superb view over the red roofs of Prague.

Follow the ancient fortifying walls to find the monument dedicated to Karel Hynek Mácha. It is customary for young couples to place flowers at its foot every 1st of May as a confirmation of their love.

‘It was the end of an evening in May / The first of May, the time to love. / The tender call of the doves / Rose with the smell of pines. / The moss spoke of secret embraces…' (Excerpt from May, 1836).

Petřín Hill
169 00 Prague 6

content.title: The Mucha Museum: the Mecca of Art Nouveau

introduction.small: In the historic city centre, the Kaunic Palace is home to the Mucha Museum, the first in the world dedicated to the work of Art Nouveau master Alphonse Mucha.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Mucha Museum: the Mecca of Art Nouveau

paragraphs.text:
Dedicated to the work of Alphonse Mucha, the museum in his name is a paradise for lovers of the Art Nouveau style. Renowned for the complexity of his theatre posters, Mucha created postcards, ads, and illustrations.

After moving to Paris in 1886, the artist rose to international fame while working with actress Sarah Bernhardt. The museum houses a superb collection of sketches, paintings, photographs, and statues by this great Czech painter, who was also an interior designer and decorator.

Besides the monumental series of 20 paintings dedicated to the history of the Slavic people, the Slav Epic, now housed in the hall of the Veletržní Palace, Mucha decorated Prague's National Theatre and the Municipal House, thanks to the intervention of American philanthropist Charles Richard Crane.

Mucha Museum
Kaunický Palác, Panská 7
110 00 Nové Město

+420 224 216 415

www.mucha.cz

content.title: Mosaic House: design and youth culture

introduction.small: The Mosaic House is a hip, green address in the new city offering top-quality services close to Prague's historic centre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mosaic House: design and youth culture

paragraphs.text:
The young at heart can treat themselves to a penthouse or a double room with terrace at the Mosaic House, a hotel that is also a youth hostel.

Younger guests go for the backpacker ethos of the collective accommodations and private bathrooms with Villeroy & Boch fittings. It's the most ecologically-minded address in the Czech Republic. The Loca Music Bar & Lounge provides an exclusive food offer consisting of crossover cuisine all day. In the evening, the stage is set to deliver exciting music program including karaoke nights, DJ sets, live concerts, theme parties and more. With scrumptious breakfast selection, art installations, retro bikes rental on-site, movie nights, common kitchen for guests staying in shared rooms and endless other activities in the hotel, it is clear Mosaic House strives to be the hotel to remember just as the hotel's motto says: "One House, 1000 memories".

A great address in an animated neighbourhood near the Old Town.

Mosaic House
Odborů 278/4
120 00 Nové Město

+420 277 016 880

www.mosaichouse.com

Rooms: from 1300 CZK

content.title: Patriotic intelligentsia at Café Slavia

introduction.small: Czech intellectuals have been gathering at Café Slavia, the most famous and exclusive café in the capital, since the end of the 19th century.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Patriotic intelligentsia at Café Slavia

paragraphs.text:
The windows of this unique space look out over the National Theatre, a symbol of the national renaissance, and over Prague Castle, a reminder of the city's glorious past. The Vltava river flows below. The café's functional style is heightened by French Art Deco wall treatments.
Claude Fernandez, in The Murder of Disillusion, described its atmosphere: “The woodwork, details, chairs, tables were tinted in colours… recalling browned pastries, milk, cream, chocolate, coffee, chicory. I loved this correspondence between the appearance of the place and its function.' Along these lines are the red of the carpeting—that of wine, not of the Soviets!—the radiant light of the copper-capped wall sconces, and the dazzling clock above the counter, ‘resembling an enormous pomegranate.” Whether for a drink or a bite, from morning to night, the international brasserie menu is complemented with Czech specialities like beef tartare in truffle oil served with a caper tapenade and marinated shallots, duck in oven with cabbage, potato balls with onions, and homemade chocolate truffles.The windows of this unique space look out over the National Theatre, a symbol of the national renaissance, and over Prague Castle, a reminder of the city's glorious past. The Vltava river flows below. The café's functional style is heightened by French Art Deco wall treatments.
Claude Fernandez, in The Murder of Disillusion, described its atmosphere: “The woodwork, details, chairs, tables were tinted in colours… recalling browned pastries, milk, cream, chocolate, coffee, chicory. I loved this correspondence between the appearance of the place and its function.' Along these lines are the red of the carpeting—that of wine, not of the Soviets!—the radiant light of the copper-capped wall sconces, and the dazzling clock above the counter, ‘resembling an enormous pomegranate.” Whether for a drink or a bite, from morning to night, the international brasserie menu is complemented with Czech specialities like beef tartare in truffle oil served with a caper tapenade and marinated shallots, duck in oven with cabbage, potato balls with onions, and homemade chocolate truffles.

Café Slavia
Smetanovo nábř. 1012/2
110 00 Staré Město

www.cafeslavia.cz

Menu: from 11 EUR

content.title: Don Giovanni at the Estates Theatre

introduction.small: The Estates Theatre (whose name refers to the Estates of the Bohemian crown) is the only theatre still standing in which Mozart played. Baroque magnificence since 1783.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Don Giovanni at the Estates Theatre

paragraphs.text:
At the end of the 18th century, Prague opened its arms to Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, whose The Marriage of Figaro had been poorly received by the Viennese public.

To thank the city for its hospitality, Mozart dedicated his Symphony No. 38 in D Major to it and composed one of his most famous works, the opera Don Giovanni, here. The premier was held at the Estates Theatre on 29 October 1787. Take advantage of your stay to discover this fabulous Baroque building and a rich programme of ballets and operas.

At intermission, enjoy a glass of Bohemia Sekt sparkling wine. But beware of the magical charm of the setting: around the corner may be the famously intimidating statue known as the Commander!

Estates Theatre
Železná
110 00 Staré Město

+420 224 901 448

www.narodni-divadlo.cz

content.title: Old Town Square: the centre of Czech life

introduction.small: It is one of the most famous squares in Europe, a historical jewel surrounded by palaces, churches, and the former mayor's office with its unforgettable astronomical clock.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Old Town Square: the centre of Czech life

paragraphs.text:
An 11th-century marketplace, Old Town Square is today one of the city's most animated areas, featuring charming café terraces, magnificent Gothic churches, and ornate palaces.

It is located between two of Prague's other major monuments, the Charles Bridge and Wenceslas Square. Pause for a moment by the central sculpture of Jan Hus, a religious reformer who was burned at the stake. Note the small white crosses inscribed on the cobblestones, which memorialise the 27 leaders of the rebellion against the Habsburgs who were beheaded here on 12 June 1621.

Finally, don't miss the moment when the famous astronomical clock, built in 1410, strikes the hour!

Old Town Square
Staroměstské nám.
110 00 Staré Město

+420 221 714 444

www.prague.eu

content.title: The Augustine Hotel: an elegant touch of Cubism

introduction.small: The Augustine Hotel, in Malá Strana, is located in a former monastery and boasts the only spa in the world to be listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Augustine Hotel: an elegant touch of Cubism

paragraphs.text:
Prague's most beautiful Baroque church, Saint Nicolas, is only 200 metres from the tiny alleyway in the Malá Strana neighbourhood where the Augustine is hidden. The hotel is named after the 13th-century monastery that previously stood on the location. The establishment, created by London design firm RDD and hotelier Olga Polizzi, mixes eras to great effect. Carefully tended gardens and brick alcoves pair beautifully with clean-lined contemporary furnishings. Touches of moss green and burnt orange bring particular personality to the 101 rooms and 20 suites. The terrace offers panoramic views of Prague. With the only spa in the world listed as a UNESCO World Heritage site, an elegant restaurant overlooking the courtyard, and its own beer created by monks at the St. Thomas Bar, the Augustine is one of the most in-demand hotels in Prague.

Augustine Hotel
Letenská 33/12
110 00 Malá Strana

+420 266 112 233

www.augustinehotel.com

Rooms: from 270 EUR

content.title: Funky, Friendly Fusion

introduction.small: In a Cubist setting designed by Joseph Gočár, the Fusion Hotel plays with styles and moods in its revolving bar-lounge and themed rooms.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Funky, Friendly Fusion

paragraphs.text:
Located only steps away from Wenceslas Square, Fusion has been offering, besides the more traditional and inexpensive lodgings, themed rooms (Fusion, White, Vintage, Love, and Rock) since 2012.

All the rooms and suites have been decorated by young Czech artists. Sip a cocktail in the large bar-lounge, which turns full circle underneath a glass dome. Friendly and welcoming, the hotel even offers smoking areas.

Enjoy a light meal in the distinctive bistro Soup in the City which vibrates with the sounds of a live DJ every weekend.

Fusion Hotel
Panská 9
110 00 Praha 1

+420 226 222 800

www.fusionhotels.com

Rooms: from 1,840 CZK

content.title: La Dégustation: traditional yet modern

introduction.small: La Dégustation Bohême Bourgeoise, Prague's not-to-be-missed gastronomic address, offers a progressive revamp of Czech culinary heritage.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Dégustation: traditional yet modern

paragraphs.text:
La Dégustation Bohême Bourgeoise owes its reputation to the creativity of chef Oldřich Sahajdák, who revisits traditional Czech dishes via his inspired take on French cuisine.

Very much like Alain Passard, the chef of Arpège in Paris whom he admires, Sahajdák grows his own organic produce. Less than 500 metres from the Old Town Square, the restaurant pairs smoked beef tongue with vinegary shallots and puréed chickpeas, oyster mushrooms with horseradish sauce and tapioca pearls.

The decor is sober but chic, the wine selection serious. The bill reflects La Dégustation's status as one of the only Michelin-starred restaurants in the capital.

La Dégustation Bohême Bourgeoise
Haštalská 18
110 00 Staré Město

+420 222 311 234

www.ladegustation.cz

Menu: around 2,700 CZK

content.title: Between two shores: the Charles Bridge

introduction.small: Unaffected by floods for 700 years, the Charles Bridge symbolically links Western and Eastern Europe with its triumphant parade of religious sculpture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Between two shores: the Charles Bridge

paragraphs.text:
Symbol of Prague, the Charles Bridge is a true work of architectural art. Built in the 14th century and the only link between the bourgeois side of the city, the Staré Město, and that of the nobles, the Malá Strana, until 1841, the construction, 500 metres long, is entirely pedestrian.

Come late in the evening or early in the morning to avoid the unending lines of tourists, and wander along the double corridor formed by the lampposts and the baroque statuary of saints.

Aloft between two shores, the Charles Bridge symbolises the physical location of the Czech capital: it links the eastern and western portions of the city as well as Eastern and Western Europe, and like the Saint Angelus Bridge in Rome, it links the sacred to the profane, the sky to the earth.

Charles Bridge
Karlův most
